text: my name is Ned Benson and I'm the writer
director of the disappearance of Eleanor
Rigby them him and her would you still
love me if I couldn't pay for dinner so
this is the opening scene of the
disappearance of Eleanor Rigby them and
actually the disappearance of Eleanor
Rigby him what I was doing here was uh
creating a long fluid tracking shot that
introduces the characters which are
Connor Ludlow played by James McAvoy and
Eleanor Rigby played by Jessica Chastain
and I wanted to capture an early moment
of their relationship and sort of sit
with them as if we were a person sitting
at the table next to him sort of
overhearing what they're going through
and ultimately I'm Connor has just told
Eleanor that he he doesn't have money to
pay for dinner and she says okay figure
it out I love you see you later and and
steps out on him and Connor realizes
that he has to dash out with her
initially this shot had been like a
four-minute tracking shot that followed
James all the way through the East
Village from an ATM into the restaurant
and out but what I realized is that it
was a bit superfluous and sort of later
in the editorial process we thought it
would be you know my editor the producer
and myself sort of sat with it and
thought the best way to open this film
that is a love story is to open and on
the two characters themselves in media
res and then obviously they're running
out into the street here together and
into the park this scene in reality
years before when I first started
writing the script I was in Central Park
actually on a summer night and had this
beautiful moment where all these
fireflies started to flare so I wanted
to recreate that in this
you know with these this couple you know
in this moment because it just seemed
very cinematic and romantic way to start
a film and ultimately these fireflies in
this moment becomes a mnemonic and
something that the couple references
throughout the films do we lose him the
crazy thing about this night aside from
the fact that we had shot this long
crazy tracking shot when they were
running that our dolly had actually
fallen off the tracks and and thrown our
dolly grip my DP and another grip which
was a bit crazy we did ultimately get a
beautiful shot out of it but um before
that when we came to set up we walked
into the park and it's very rare to have
fireflies in New York City much less
Tompkins Square Park and I'm the one
night that we're shooting we get these
thousands of fireflies that are flaring
and that was pretty incredible as a park
ranger who was supervising the shoot
said it's very rare and I think the
night before and the night after because
we were shooting in the park then they
weren't there you know or at least they
were there and removed to a much lesser
extent so we were able to capture magic
that I was trying to recreate from all
these years before so that was a pretty
special evening and it was one of our
last nights or at least in our last week
of shooting so it was a pretty special
way to go out
